I've inherited a huge codebase which I'll be taking over development for; a=
s soon as
possible, I want to put skeletal JUnit tests in place for every c=
lass; as I perform
refactorings, and as I introduce new functionality, my i=
ntention is to first flesh out
JUnit tests, before adding feature/refactori=
ng.

This raises several questions, most of all related to what are the bes=
t practices
for keeping Unit Tests alongside code.

Options as I see them:
=

1.    A separate directory tree with a root note of test, the package stru=
cture of
      which reflects that of the codebase; keep the tests complete=
ly isolated from
      production code, the downside being that if I refact=
or code around packages,
      I have to remember to move tests as well; al=
so, removes my ability to test
      private and protected methods..

2.   =
 A 'test' directory in each package of the codebase, containing TestXXXX
  =
    classes; with a TestXXXX class for each XXXX class in the package above=
.
      Again, can't test public/protected methods, and a little extra work=
 is     
      required to remove tests from production code, but not that =
much.

3.    Actually make each class in the production code it's own test,=
 ie put the
      JUnit testing code in the class itself.  This gives me ac=
cess to protected
      and private methods, AND makes it easy to refactor =
and move tests around.
      Another upside is that the JUnit plugin for To=
gether UML will create all
      these test skeletons for me in this manner=
.  Downside (and I see it as a 
      pretty big downside) is that my JUnit=
 tests are all but impossible to remove
      from my production code.

Has=
 anyone got any thoughts on this problem ?    Anyone been in a similar
situ=
ation, and got suggestions they could offer ?

Cheers,

Steven
